title: Boris Johnson looks to an election with promise to make UK ‘greatest place on earth’
text:
Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson | Pool photo by Jeremy Selwyn/AFP via Getty Images Boris Johnson looks to an election with promise to make UK ‘greatest place on earth’ ‘The only legitimate way to sort Brexit now is to let the people decide with a final say,’ Jeremy Corbyn says.

LONDON — Boris Johnson thinks Brexit can make Britain great again.

The queen's speech, the ritualistic state opening of the U.K. parliament in which the monarch sets out the government's plan for legislation, was dominated by Brexit Monday, with both leaders of the two main parties eyeing a likely general election.

In a foreword to the speech published shortly after the queen spoke, the prime minister pledged to use Brexit to make the U.K. “the greatest place on earth.”

“Let’s not wait, we can’t wait, let’s get Brexit done,” he told MPs later Monday afternoon, adding that Brexit would allow the U.K. to “regulate differently and better,” develop its own immigration system and control its fisheries and agricultural policy.

The queen set out the policy priorities of Johnson's government in a list of 26 bills, covering domestic policy including crime, immigration, health and the environment.

The speech comes as negotiators intensify talks in a push to get a deal between the U.K. and the EU agreed before European leaders meet in Brussels Thursday.

However, the Labour leader attacked the government for presenting an agenda that is unlikely to go anywhere until there is a general election.

"There has never been such a farce as a government with a majority of minus 45 and a 100 percent record of defeat in the House of Commons setting out a legislative agenda they know cannot be delivered in this parliament," Corbyn said.

Corbyn said the government has “failed” to resolve Brexit after three and a half years, and that the matter now requires a fresh referendum, with no mention of an election. "The only legitimate way to sort Brexit now is to let the people decide with a final say,” he said.

The comments came in contrast to Corbyn’s carefully worded warning on Sunday, where he said he would “caution” against Labour MPs backing Johnson’s Brexit deal on the condition that it was put to a referendum. He told Sky’s Sophy Ridge: “I would want a deal that resembles the five pillars that we put forward.”

He was contradicted by close ally Rebecca Long-Bailey, who told the BBC’s Andrew Marr Show the same day that she would support attaching a referendum to any deal Johnson struck.

Corbyn told the Commons Monday: “To pass this House, any deal needs to meet the needs of workers and businesses. That means including a new customs union, a close single market relationship and guarantees of worker’s rights, consumer standards and environmental protections.” He added that it should not undermine the Good Friday Agreement.

The speech comes as negotiators intensify talks in a push to get a deal between the U.K. and the EU agreed before European leaders meet in Brussels Thursday. Johnson is legally bound to seek an extension to the current Brexit deadline of October 31 if he does not get a deal through the Commons by October 19, despite having consistently opposed any extension to negotiations.

Briefing notes attached to the speech say the government intends to negotiate a Brexit deal with “a new protocol on Ireland/Northern Ireland” that does not include a backstop, a reference to the mechanism designed to avoid a hard border on the island of Ireland that has been widely rejected by MPs. Achieving this depends on the outcome of U.K. officials’ talks with the EU this week.

The document mentions a no-deal Brexit just once, saying: “On 4 September, the government set out its policy on post-exit immigration arrangements in a no deal scenario. Free movement as it currently stands will end on 31 October.”

In the event of no deal, EU citizens will be able to apply for temporary immigration status before January 2021, which will give them the right to remain in the U.K. for three years.
description: ‘The only legitimate way to sort Brexit now is to let the people decide with a final say,’ Jeremy Corbyn says.
